content.value: Advanced shell scripting uses logic, conditions, loops, and functions to automate complex tasks in Linux.
This lets us make decisions in scripts, repeat tasks automatically, and organize code into reusable functions—just like small programs.

value: Check if commands succeeded or failed

content.value: Always start small: build scripts in pieces, test often!
Conditions help scripts behave differently depending on user input or system state.

content.command:
#!/bin/bash
if [ -f file.txt ]; then
  echo "file exists"
else
  echo "file not found"
fi
content.description: Check if a file exists before taking action.

content.value: Space matters in conditions: [ value -eq 10 ] ✔️  NOT [value- eq10] ❌
Loops repeat tasks—great for backups, automation, processing files, and system checks.

content.command:
for file in *.txt; do
  echo "Processing $file"
done
content.description: Loop through all text files in a directory.

content.command:
while true; do
  echo "Running..."
  sleep 2
done
content.description: An infinite loop (use CTRL + C to stop).

content.value: for = repeat over a list; while = repeat until condition stops.
Functions organize logic and make scripts cleaner, easier to maintain, and reusable.
